com.greenfabric.find
Class GnuNativeFind

java.lang.Object
  com.greenfabric.find.GnuNativeFind
class GnuNativeFind
extends java.lang.Object

This uses the GNU utilities bash, find and perl to perform the same function as the Java-only Find class. It is meant to be used only from within this package.

Author:
Robb Shecter, robb@acm.org

Constructor Summary
(package private) GnuNativeFind(Find f)
          Construct a new GnuNativeFind that gathers the information as specified by the given platform independent find.
 
Method Summary

          Return true if this current environment seems to support everything I need to execute smoothly.
(package private)  void gnuFind(StdOutConsumer consumer)
          Fill the given Vector with filenames, using the GNU utilities.

Constructor Detail

GnuNativeFind

GnuNativeFind(Find f)
        throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
Construct a new GnuNativeFind that gathers the information as specified by the given platform independent find.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the current operating system is not based on GNU or does not have bash, find and perl installed. This is a runtime exception, and so does not have to be trapped by the application programmer.
Method Detail

canFunction

static boolean canFunction()
Return true if this current environment seems to support everything I need to execute smoothly. This should be called first before constructing an instance of this class. Note that this method isnï¿½t rock-solid safe because it doesn't try executing the programs, and it doesn't issue a version command to make sure they're really GNU and accept all of the required options. I made the decision not to do this kind of checking in the interest of time-efficiency. I think that chances are good enough that if the first tests pass, then this class can function. If not, a runtime error is thrown, and the user must fix their system. (Good idea? How much time -would- it take to verify that the programs can really be executed?)

One idea would be to leave things in this method as they are, but to allow Find to use the Java-only implementation if this one has a problem executing.

gnuFind

void gnuFind(StdOutConsumer consumer)
       throws java.io.IOException
Fill the given Vector with filenames, using the GNU utilities. This method does all the work of building the find and perl command line. It's the messiest part of this package.

Throws:
java.io.IOException
